result.markdown:
--- title: "Have Airlines Safety Improve Over Time ✈️?" author: "Josephine Valensia" date: "2022-09-06" categories: [Article] image: "image.jpg" bibliography: references.bib css: "style.css" execute: echo: false warning: false message: false --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: Seeing news about flight accidents, airplane crashed, does it make you question airline safety? Does it make you afraid to fly? Regardless of the major flight incidents happened, according to a study by Massachusetts Institute of Technology(MIT), flying on commercial airlines actually has never been safer [@dizikes_2020]. The study has found that the passenger fatalities has been decreasing, even for the long term. In this article, we will dive into past airlines performance, analyse the data and answer the question: "Have airline safety really improved these past decades?" ## About the data The data for this article is sourced from [TidyTuesday](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2018/2018-08-07), which has been modified from the original data by [Aviation Safety Network](https://aviation-safety.net/). The data contains 336 observations and 6 variables. These variables are: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Variable Class Description
X integer Number of observations
airline character Airline (asterisk indicates that regional subsidiaries are included)
avail_seat_km_per_week double Available seat kilometers flown every week
year_range character Range of year (1985-1999 & 2000-2014)
type_of_event character Types of events happened : incidents, fatal accidents, fatalities
n_events integer Total number of event that happened
````` ::: ::: ## Analysis Let's first look at the overall trend between the range of year 1985-1999 and 2000-2014 for each type of the events. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {#tbl-diff .cell tbl-cap='Average number of incidents, fatal accidents and fatalities had decreased, comparing both range of years.'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Type of event 1985-1999 2000-2014 Difference(%)
incidents 7.179 4.125 -42.537
fatal accidents 2.179 0.661 -69.672
fatalities 112.411 55.518 -50.612
````` ::: ::: From the @tbl-diff above we can see that airlines did become more safe as the number of incidents, fatal accidents and fatalities had decreased. On average the number of occurrence in the period 2000-14 has decline roughly half compared to 1985-1999. This finding is also supported by [@barnett_2020] study which claim that the accident risk indeed declined by a factor of two every decade. ::: {.column-margin} > "The worldwide risk of being killed had been dropping by a factor of two every decade." - [@barnett_2020]. ::: Now we know that the overall trend is decreasing, we will take a closer look to each type of the events. #### Incidents To compare the number of incidents during both period, I will take the top 10 airlines with the highest number of incidents occurred in 1985-1999 and 2000-2014. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Top 10 airlines with the highest number of incidents in 1985-99 and 2000-14](index_files/figure-html/fig-inc-1.png){#fig-inc width=1152} ::: ::: The @fig-inc shows the airlines with the most incidents in both range of years. Despite of 4 airlines from the US that stays in the top 10, with Delta Airlines having the same number of incidents in both period, looking in the overall number of incidents, the numbers did decreased with the highest of 24 incidents in 2000-2014, which has dropped almost 70% from 1985-1999. #### Fatal Accidents Within those incidents, there are few numbers that are fatal causing fatalities. Similarly, we will compare the 10 airlines with the highest number of fatal accidents in 1985-1999 and 2000-2014. ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {#fig-fatal .cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` Top 10 airlines with the highest number of fatal accidents in 1985-99 and 2000-14 ::: ::: Clearly, we can see from @fig-fatal a significant difference especially in the top 5 rank. On average in 1985-1999 there are 3.5 times more fatal accidents occurred than in 2000-2014. We can contrast the difference looking at the first rank, Aeroflot with 14 fatal accidents in 1985-1999 compared to American Airlines with just 3 fatal accidents in 2000-2014. This indicates a big improvement in airline safety preventing fatal accidents over the years. #### Fatalities ::: {.cell} ::: Fatal accidents caused fatalities, risking the crews and the passengers live. Along with the declining incident and fatal accident number, we will analyse did the fatality rate also decreases.
::: {#tbl-fatalities .cell tbl-cap='Average number of fatalities in 10 million seats'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Average number of fatalities in 10 million seats
1985-1999 2000-2014 Difference (%)
1.297 0.648 -50.058
````` ::: :::
The rate of fatalities is calculated following the method used by @silver_2014. Dividing the number of fatalities by the number of available seat kilometers(ASK) flown every week, with the assumption that the airlines have the same ASK over the years. @tbl-fatalities indicates that, on average, the rate of fatalities has dropped by half with potential risk of 0.6 in 10 million by 2000-2014. It means that only 1 people over 17 million seats offered by the airlines potentially have the risk to be in a fatal accident. ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Number of fatalities in 10 million seats](index_files/figure-html/fig-fatalities-1.png){#fig-fatalities fig-align='center' width=672} ::: ::: Moreover, most airlines with high rate of fatalities in 1985-1999, such as Avianca, Pakistan International and China Airlines were unlikely to have high rate of fatalities in the next decades as shown in @fig-fatalities. On the other side, despite the fact that airlines that had low fatality rate in 1985-1999 did not perform well and resulted in a higher rate of fatalities in 2000-2014, like Kenya Airways, Malaysia Airlines and Gulf Air, the fatality rate of the other airlines was shown to be lower. ## So, Have airline safety really improved these past decades? Based on our analysis of the number of incidents, fatal accidents and rate of fatalities, comparing data from two period of year, 1985-1999 and 2000-2014, we can say that airline safety had improved. Each of the airlines also showed improvement of their safety performance resulting in a huge drop of incidents and fatalities. Moreoever, in the latest report from International Air Transport Association [@iata] also finds that "long-term accident trends confirm that aviation is getting safer". Therefore, do not worry to fly as AIRLINE SAFETY REALLY HAVE IMPROVED and is getting safer. ## The following are the OS system and R-packages used for this article: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` ─ Session info ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── setting value version R version 4.1.2 (2021-11-01) os macOS Monterey 12.4 system aarch64,
